This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/irjBdbwU5dp Printed on a single extruder Makerbot, just pause the job and switch filament when text is printing or just use a maker / paint afterwards.
This hand-sized spider is perfect for scaring someone you know! It prints out quickly - 2 hours for the body, 30 minutes for the legs.

The sample was printed in ABS, but I'm sure PLA will work too. Print the body with supports. I kept the fill low 10% and every 2 layers. The belly of the spider fused a bit to the plate. It might be a good idea to use a 4ish layer raft for a better bottom finish. The legs are printed on a 2 layer raft with supports. When removing the legs from the print bed, keep track of each legs number - you'll need it for assembly. Remove only the parts of the raft and supports that fall away easily. the rest is left on to make the legs look hairy. Use the numbered picture to mark the location of the legs as you take them off the bed. Paint:
Paint the hourglass shape and eyes using red paint. I used a paint marker. You may need to paint more than one coat. Leg Assembly:
When looking at the spider body from above with the head up, the legs are placed like the numbers on a clock. Cement the legs in one at a time alternating sides. The legs will support the spider when dry, until then rest the belly of the spider on something about 1/2 inch high. Antennae:
These should fit in either slot on the head. They will need to be supported until dry. The original file was modeled in Cinema 4D. Message me if you want a copy sent to you to do your own variations.

comments.text:
I think you are right the raft pieces work well left on the legs.
Two things about the hour glass.
-It's supposed to be on the bottom, but everyone puts it on top so you can see it. Wrong but understandable.
-In the case of your design it is a shame it isn't a button. I'm not even there and I want to press it. :-)
Maybe a small wav sound circuit to make a hiss/roar when someone presses it?
Nice job.

description.text: Microstepping for great justice These new stepper drivers are capable of doing 1/8 stepping which means that instead of jerking from one position to the next, the stepper motor will gradually move between them. This results in lower vibrations, lower noise, and better precision. Your machine will be quieter, print better, and create world peace. Highly configurable and tunable While this driver works great out of the box, we've added a bunch of configuration options to this board if you want to get into the nitty gritty of stepper driver operation. There is a dip switch selector to change the stepping mode between full, half, 1/4, and 1/8 step. The current control is also completely configurable with four potentiometers with large test points so that you can set the current, decay mode, and RC constants. With this you can tune the stepper driver to perfectly suit your stepper motor. High power output The chip we're using is capable of handling up to 2.8A per phase, so you can easily control motors up to NEMA23 size. The provided power connector allows you to easily power it off a standard ATX power supply, but if you're feeling adventurous, the chip can handle up to 35V for the drive voltage. You'll have to wire up your own connector though.
Full instructions at MakerBot: http://wiki.makerbot.com/thingomatic-doc:stepper-driver-3-3

comments.text: ="thingiverse-d0509bdcf257b525756b981d54351da6:disqus" href="http://disqus.com/thingiverse-d0509bdcf257b525756b981d54351da6/camstuff You need a different STL file for each colour, normally we find its best to make one part/model file in the program of your choice, with a feature for each colour. Once you've built the entire model with every colour, just chop and cut out material or deactivate features until only one colour remains, save as an STL, and rinse repeat for the remaining colours. Then the STLs can be loaded into the RepRapPro Slicer software for printing - it's still beta but functional and print quality is improving by the day. We're working on modifications to Slic3r - it will do multi-colour prints - but it doesn't handle extruder changes very well at the moment. An openscad script for one of our test pieces is included in ="thingiverse-806fec5af7f5b48b8a31a003e171f3fb:disqus" href="http://disqus.com/thingiverse-806fec5af7f5b48b8a31a003e171f3fb/jmgiacalone 's link for reference.

description.text:
For those times when the grass is just a bit too long and it gets tangled up in your propellers as you try to take off, use this handy folding launch platform to raise the quadcopter up a bit.  
Designed for a DJI F450 frame to sit on, but will probably work just fine with other quadcopters too.  Folds flat to fit easily into your bag or pocket.  
Note this isnt supposed to be attached to your quadcopter and should remain on the ground as you take off.

Print 4 arms and 2 centre joins and fasten them together with 2 M3 bolts.  All parts can printed in a single print run if you face the centres of the arms into the centre of the print bed for printing.

comments.text: Hopefully this only applies to my 3d printer package. I have a Prusa 3D printer variant from a company called Monoprice. They included a version of Cura software with their system. My primary computer for running the Cura is running Windows 8.1. At any rate, when I finished printing my first 2 arms, I found that I only had a complete outer shell on one outer surface, the "outside". The outer surface for the two curved surfaced leading to the feet, and the outer surface "next" to the pivot point are incomplete; that is, there are two "walls" extending through the arm at about a quarter-inch in from the pivot. To my mind, this means that should any one of the arms come under severe stress, that it could break off at that point. Do I need to look into another program to generate the gcode file for my printer?

description.text: A new version of this is available! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:608339

It's a flippin' folding phone stand! This phone stand has 5 angle settings: 30°, 45°, 50°, 55° and 60°. Suitable for most smartphones not thicker than 12mm.
It may also be suitable for tablets if you enlarge the models. 2D dimensions: 40mm x 60mm
Thickness of each part: 4mm
Holder notches length: 13.7mm (external), 10.5mm - 12.2mm (internal)
Holder notches gap: 21mm No bolts required, just print and assemble.
This thing is created with FreeCAD. Source files included.

• Print with no support. The backplate model already contains custom brim and support for easier printing, but you can remove them or print with additional brim as you like.
    • The recommended layer height is 0.1mm with 0.2mm first layer.
    • For the stand model you can use a 0.2mm or 0.25mm layer height for z from 4mm to 13mm if your slicer supports it.
    • If you use an extra brim, make sure to clean up the brim around the hinge axles.
  • Cut away the brim and support.
  • Assemble the stand according to the figure. There is a flat position on the hinge which allows easier insertion at a certain angle. (Note that the figure doesn't show the flat position.)
  • Flip and place phone on it. :)

Around the world in 80 prints.
=======================
We’ll set a route of 80 3D printers each in a country neighbouring the prior one, and will send our traveller, the fifth filament, to 3D printing people in these countries, asking them to print it, take a picture of it in front of a landmark, and send these pictures back to us with some lines of text, and if they like their contact data , so we can make a blogpost of it.
http://www.aroundtheworldin80prints.org
We want you

Join in and print your 5th Filament, and upload pics to our freesytel section. Or add a personalised QR-Code or weblink to your print and set it free (leave it where someome will find it). Track it with its unique id, and see when finders add a message or photos to its journal.
This is non commercial free project, just to spread the ideas of 3d printing around the world.

Print it in whatever material, color or size you like. It's a very simple print. Print the 5th filament and the stand, put them together. Ignore the body.stl and heart.stl Done.
You can print it in two colors, even with a single extruede. Just pause the print after printing the body and change the filament color to print the 8bit heart.
For dual extruders there are files with a separated body and heart.
Or you print them seperated in different colors and glue them together.
Than take a picture and upload it at atwi8p.org freestyle section.

comments.text: Follow the journey on twitter: #atwi8p
comments.author: 3dlyx

comments.text: We are still looking for 3d printers along the 'official' route around the world. If you want to help us on this journey, just drop a message on the contact form on atwi8p.org . If we can fit you into the route, we will send you a special version of the 5th Filament, with the number of the waypoint on it. We mark your printers location on the route map, along with a blogpost with the conatct data and images you want to provide and your thoughts about the project or 3d printing in general.
comments.author: 3dlyx

description.text: Revised version of Duran's iPhone 6 blank case and sized it to remove a bit of vertical slack the original had and I split it in half to fit nicely in my Up! Mini.

Recommend printing in PLA at 0.2mm layer height or smaller with no raft and minimal supports to ensure easy removal.
v1.1 - updated the top half to remove the need to put any pressure on the power button. Assemble by pushing the lower half onto the phone first, then slide the top half on from the volume button side, then clipping over the far edge where the power button is.
Note the sections are a very exact fit when printed on the Up Mini so you may need to push gently on them to align and let the pieces lock together. Alternatively use a craft knife and run around the inside edge of the locking tabs to give them an angled edge to slot in.

description.text:
I couldn't find a good place to sit my new Quirky Wink Hub when it arrived, so I whipped up this simple wall mount. It has three slip-ons for screws on the back so you can hang it with two for more stability and level or just use the center hole by itself to hang it quick and easy. The hub doesn't attach to the mount so you can easily reach the plug and reset button whenever you like. I did give the printed base a slight backward lean and a lip on the from so it should stay put for uneven walls or, in our case, major thunderstorms shaking things.

This requires no supports or assembly...print away!

description.text: Simple, repeatable, reliable The mechanical endstop is a simple solution to a simple problem. We want to be able to detect when an X/Y/Z stage has reached its minimum or maximum. Instead of messing with flags or complicated light beam interruptors, we use a mechanical switch. If we place the switch in the path of the stage, then the stage itself will simply close the switch when it moves against it. Other than properly positioning the switch, we do not need to modify the stage at all. If you're worried about reliability, you can sleep well at night. The switches we use are rated for 1 million operations before failure. Since we only use the switches once per print, that means you'll be able to do one million prints before having to replace the switch.
Full instructions here: http://wiki.makerbot.com/thingomatic-doc:mechanical-endstop-1-2

You can change the original SolidWorks file to customize it.
Thank you for your like!
Simple roller bearing with 8 captured rollers. 1/4" square center post, approx. 1.38" (35mm) outer diameter, 1/2" thick.

• Update 13Oct14: loosened up the spacing between rollers and inner and outer rings; can now be broken loose w/o tools.
    • I printed this with my Printrbot Simple Metal out of PLA (on mine I use 75% filament flow to get better dimensional accuracy). The design uses all curved notches and bump-outs, and the rollers start flat, so no support material is required. Must be printed all at once, as the rollers are captured. I've printed both .1mm and .2mm layer thickness; print at 100% infill, and make sure the center of the rollers are solid or they may snap.
    ***
    Designed for a filament cradle for my Printrbot, but could also be used as a pulley.
    ***
    I've also included the Sketchup (8) source for tweaking and adapting.

author: PaulBadeuille

description.text:
This is a holder I drew up to keep the items that came with my replicator together. It's got spots for the allen keys, the manual, the packet of lubrication, and the big sheets of painter's tape. I've made some revisions to my original file, since a lot of people seemed interested in it. I haven't printed out a revised version yet, but I tried to accomplish the following:
-Trim away as much excess material as I could to cut down on print times.
-Widen the holes for the allen keys so they're not so snug
-Add a little more support on the bottom so it doesn't flop around on the back of the machine so much
-Made a version with little wings on the side, which should be the right size to store my spool holders of different diameters when they're not in use. Still need to look into SD slots, holders for other tools, etc.

Print it out, flip it over, and clip it into the spot where a 2nd spool would go on your replicator 2.
I tried to draw everything so that it would print without needing any support or assembly.  It prints upside-down.  I printed my first test with the standard low quality settings, and it required quite a bit of cleanup.  Also the small holes for the allen keys ended up TOO small, and the outer corners peeled up from the bed a bit.  It also took 8 hours to print!  At higher quality I'm sure the hole diameter and peeling issues would be resolved, but it would take all day to print.  
I'm going to do a further revision with a couple SD slots, maybe some other tool slots, or a hook for rolls of masking tape, but hopefully also shave away a bunch of material to make it print faster.

comments.text: I was using lowest quality settings and it took less time than that, something like 6 hours.  Still working on a version that's a lot slimmer so that it doesn't take FOREVER to make.  But, it's big, so it's bound to take some time.

Integrated heat, temperature sensting, and motor control The Thingomatic Heater Board is mashup of innovative 3D printing techniques. The heater board fulfils a number of roles in the Thingomatic. First, it provides a nice, flat printing surface with mounting holes. Second, the PCB itself is one large, flat heater which provides very even heating across the surface. Third, the PCB includes an on-board thermistor which allows the board to measure its own temperature. Last, but not least, the PCB includes a header for connecting it to the rest of the MakerBot electronics so that you can easily wire it up.
Full details here: http://wiki.makerbot.com/thingomatic-doc:thingomatic-heater-board-1-1

If You cannot visit those famous graves, they can visit You.
uploaded some point cloud files - you can use it to generate higher resolution stl files if your computer is capable of such task.
it would be good to cleanup this file a bit more before reconstruction.
i might upload reconstructions when i'll get my hands on machine with enough ram to crunch the task :)
edit : tried to reconstruct bit more and got some lessons learned:
1)closeup photos provide far better detail level than many overview photos in high resolution
2)64bit machine , ddr3 or ddr4 based, 16G quad channel or more - mandatory.
www.cs.jhu.edu/~bolitho/Research/StreamingSurfaceReconstruction/
and http://www.cs.jhu.edu/~misha/Code/PoissonRecon/Version6.11/ can be some help on older systems, but the pvms alone bails out as it requires over 4G of ram for feature matching.
i did not attempt any slicing of such scans yet...
ofcourse those are over 2m high models but i bet someone with delta will finally attempt to make at least 1:2 replica ;)
3)pvms does not set up normals , even if camera positions are valid. no idea why - perhaps a bug. one needs to reconstruct normals with meshlab but it's far from perfection - many artifacts kick in :/
4)poisson surface reconstruction in meshlab is broken (infinite loops). use any of above or something completely different.

description.text: I designed these for my wife because she was bored with the unremarkable knob pulls that were on our cabinets when we moved into our new house.  They are designed to accept a 4mm diameter machine screw (hole diameter in CAD files is 4.4mm, but comes out to about 4mm when printed on a LulzBot Taz 4).  The owl and pillar print separately to eliminate the need for supports.  The pillar is 5mm long and the hole in the back of the owl is 4.5mm deep, so the screw can penetrate a total depth of 9.5mm.  Designed in Google SketchUp.  Ready-to-print gcode is included for the LulzBot Taz 4, including a panel of 4 knobs.

author: Sigmaz

description.text:
Fully Automatic With the automated build platform it will keep printing and printing. The automated build platform is truly a revolution in 3D printing. It allows you to have a print queue where your machine will clear the build surface between builds and print objects one after another. This turns your MakerBot into a little factory that sits on your desktop. Best of all, this is completely automated: you hit print, and the machine does all the work. Want to print 100 butterflies? Easy. Want to print an entire chess set? No problem. Want to start a business selling printed things that you've designed? Awesome. Have the bot do all the work while you design new things. Extremely Reliable The MK5 plastruder will give you thousands of hours of trouble-free printing. We've invested many hours into designing, testing, and tweaking the MK5 plastruder. The result is an extruder that is extremely reliable, and very simple to maintain. The hot end on this extruder is essentially unbreakable and the filament drive system is one of the strongest on the market. We've run these things for thousands of hours with minimal problems. Changing the filament is a breeze with the filament pressure thumb screw. You can even swap the filament while the extruder is running if you're fast enough. Higher Quality The layer alignment is much better which results in nicer prints and higher resolution. We've completely overhauled the drive system to give the optimum positioning accuracy. The entire system has been upgraded to sturdy 3/8" diameter linear shafting. This is probably overkill, but you can trust that the axes will be sturdy. We've also switched to self-aligning, sintered brass bearings. These are very forgiving to DIY assembly and provide a nice, smooth motion on the steel shafts. Last, but not least we've completely replaced the Z axis with a stepper driven, cantilevered stage. Guided by two of the linear shafts, this completely eliminates any Z wobble and results in nicely aligned layers. Using a high-angle lead screw, we were able to increase the speed of the Z axis from 150mm/minute to 1000mm/minute. This means the layer changes are almost completely imperceptible and reduces blobbing significantly. Easier to Use Connect over USB and hit print - the machine will detect its position and start printing. The new electronics have been designed to make the printing experience even easier than ever. The motherboard now sports an integrated USB port, so you simply plug the MakerBot in with a standard USB cable. We've also added full endstop support so that you never need to touch the XYZ axes ever again. When you hit print, the machine will automatically home itself, heat up, and begin printing. All you have to do is sit back and relax while your MakerBot does all the work. Living in the future is awesome. Oh yeah, and the electronics are all inside, so you don't have wires dangling everywhere.
Technical Specifications
  • Interface: Serial over USB or print from SD card.
  • Size: 12" W x 12" D x 16" H (roughly 300mm x 300mm x 400mm)
  • Usable Build Area:
  • With Automated Build Platform: 100mm x 100mm x 100mm
  • With Acrylic Build Platform: 110mm x 110mm x 120mm
  • Generation 4 Electronics
  • Supports up to 5 stepper drivers (XYZ + A/B)
  • Connect over USB
  • Optional LCD interface support
  • Full endstop support
  • High current mosfets to drive heated build platform and extruder heater
  • Thermocouple support for accurate temperature sensing
  • Power Usage: XX watts, standard ATX power supply.
  • Works with both 110v and 220v power.
  • Theoretical XY Positioning resolution of 0.02mm (20 microns or 0.0008")
  • Theoretical XY Maximum Feedrate of up to 5000mm/minute (roughly 200 IPM)
  • Theoretical Z Positioning resolution of 0.005mm (5 microns / or 0.0002")
  • Theoretical Z Positioning Feedrate of up to 1000mm/minutes (roughly 40 IPM)
  • Accepts 3mm polymer filament
  • Capable of printing with ABS and PLA

Full documentation is located on the MakerBot wiki at http://wiki.makerbot.com/thingomatic LASERCUT PARTS VERSION NOTES: Acrylic Middle Plate (as of 2011-05-25):

comments.text: They are not hard to find SDP/SI has them. all pulleys and belts are GT2 (industry standard metric) 6 mm wide. Makerbot stepper motors have an odd 3/16 shaft while most other use 5mm. SDP sells both sizes. The belts go by number of teeth. In all a couple of minutes of web surfing and you's have everything you need. Be sure to flip the search switch in the upper left to metric or inch based on the bore size you need.

title: Airwolf 3d v5.5 Harbor Freight Indicator Trammer

description.text:
This will hold a Harbor Freight or Grizzly indicator to the hot end bed of an Airwolf 3D v5.5. It will probably also work with the XL.
You will also need to replace the stock back cover with a flat back cover. You can find that thing here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:167459
The indicator tip might not hit your build plate before the hot end does. You can either buy a tip kit, or get a 4-48 screw of whatever length you choose to fit in the tip. I bought a 1.5" SS 4-48 pan-head screw for mine. Tip kits can be had here: http://littlemachineshop.com/products/product_view.php?ProductID=1783&category=

Print it with the finger-pull side down on the plane.
When done, you might have to ream the hole to remove burrs. I used a Harbor Freight 1/8" - 1/2" tapered reamer with very light pressure to clean it up until the dial slid in smoothly. It's important to leave "some" burrs in the hole to hold the dial in securely..otherwise it potentially could move in the hole while tramming your bed. You may also elect to paint the part with acetone before using. Especially the protrusions that wrap around the Airwolf hot end bed. Painting it with acetone will bond the layers, and produce a stronger, more reusable part.

remixed_from.title: Interactive Build Plate Levelling - Print Aid

title: Thin Wood Veneer - Interactive Build Plate Levelling - Print Aid

description.text:
Thanks to whpthomas and his thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39430

This print uses www.fused3d.com Cherry Wood Filament (LAYWOO-D3 1.75mm), which is PLA compatible (No heated bed)

I was able to level my print bed with awesome results on the Replicator2! The print uses the leveler thing plus whpthomas Rep2 ReplicatorG 200 micron profile.

So this specific print I believe is .1mm thick (don't think you can make real wood veneer this thin). You can see through to the grain in the underlying bamboo flooring

The Veneer sheet feels a little rough, almost like finger prints but just slightly rougher.

If you see the tape/acrylic through the veneer, then you bed is too low, and if it stops sticking (strings) then its too high.
Also, I edit the anchor wait time to P6000 (instead of 2000) it seems that makes a difference at the start of a build to get the wood flowing.

Edit: I had some trouble with this originally and VeryWetPaint was nice enough to fix some things and uploaded a derivative. I didn't want to leave this half finished though so now that I've printed and tested, I'm updating with new models and the original Inventor files. If I get a chance I may try to figure out how to model this in Openscad. A fun and confusing toy that will rotate freely in one directly, but when spun the opposite direction will stop, wobble, and reverse directions. More on wikipedia: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rattleback Uploaded at the request of Spacexula

You can print one or both files.  They are mirror images and differ only in the direction of preferred spin.  Print out with a heavy (preferably 100%) infill for best effect.  Sand them down until they are smooth along the axis of the long curve (note that is at an angle to the centerline of the part).
The amount of friction between the toy and surface can be the difference between reversing for only a few degrees or a few full turns so try them out on different tables, floors, etc.

author: JuFo2013

description.text:
I finally decided on something to make with Adafruit's 60 pixel rings I bought a while ago. Designed over a weekend. MADE TO FIT OVER GLASSES! Added a new half piece for smaller print beds, or beds that don't handle big prints well. This is a very simple build! Takes less than an hour to print, next to no touch-ups are needed. Just add the neopixel rings and an arduino and your good to go! Some simple soldering required. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=loCIGUPjD60 This project has an optional addition of an encoder to the arduino which lets you change the speed and brightness of the visor on the fly. I measured the current of the default speed/brightness to be about 150 mA, so most batteries will last a long time with this. Build materials:
  • 2 x small rubber bands
  • 4 x NeoPixel 1/4 60 Ring (https://www.adafruit.com/products/1768)
  • 1 x 3d printed white plastic visor
  • 1 x portable battery-pack or MintyBoost pack
  • 1 x micro-controller, I am using a teensy 2.0
  • 1 x adjustable eyeglass strap (http://www.amazon.com/Chums-Universal-Eyewear-Retainer-Black/dp/B003CJSE5O)
  • 8-10 x small zip-ties
  • 1 x Perma-Proto Quarter-sized Breadboard PCB (https://www.adafruit.com/products/1608)
    • Optional:
  • 1 x rotary encoder w/ push in button (https://www.adafruit.com/product/377)
  • 1 x 3d printed rotary encoder knob (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:51020)
    • Total cost is about $100 if you are buying everything from scratch.
    (including the neopixels, battery, arduino, eyeglass strap) Resources;
    https://learn.adafruit.com/larson-scanner-shades/software
    http://www.thefrankes.com/wp/?p=2660
    http://www.pjrc.com/teensy/td_libs_Encoder.html

Printing:
  • Print either one full piece or two halfs
  • Print it with 2 perimeters an 0% infill
  • No supports are needed
    • I used sharpie to block the light from shining into my eyes on the inside of the visor, but chrome or shiny paint might be better, maybe even silver sharpie. Electronics: See the gallery for wiring diagrams in the gallery for the neopixels with or without the encoder. I sawed off the power rails of the perma-promo board to make it the height I wanted, then soldered everything together and zip-tied to the side of the visor. title: Prusa I3 Rework Autobed leveling Version 2 - 9g Servo Mount, and arm, with Solidworks 2014 source
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I decided to finally release this after I made sure everything was working and I can say it is working beautifully after over a month. My original design (still on my machine too) was redone in many places where I saw it needed help in.
.
First spot was to make it beefier as I had to add support on the original version via a cross beam and the use of some JB Weld on the top due to flex and you DO NOT want any flex with this. Some just can't be helped due to the I3 Rework's X carriage setup and V1 of this flexed whereas V2 does not flex (at least with my ABS) in any measurable amount. With the addition of the new ribs structure the flex vanished (yay, no more need for a cross beam and JB Weld).
.
11/06/2014 - I have added a version that is easier to slice if using Slic3r as I found a section in the model was too thin after people who use Slic3r was having issues. Simplify3d did not have this issue but it sure has other issues as I have now dropped using it due to them...save your money.

Use supports similar to the ones I have pictured for the servo mount. 3 Vertical shells and 6 Top and Bottom Horizontal shells 50% infill.
.
Attach this via the two original 3mm by 30mm hot end screws (looking front to back this goes on the left hand side of the hot end assembly under the original big gear). Use a standard 9g servo motor (goes on the outside of the motor mount) with the proper arm and use the proper switch.
.
Here is where I purchased my items (you can purchase wherever this is just to show you the items needed for exact sizing): http://tinyurl.com/lnf5npa and http://goo.gl/LwO2G9
.
The small switch uses 2mm by 12mm hex cap screws.
.
The slim neck part of the arm has a function besides aesthetics as I take the two soldered switch wires and route them there and zip tied them up and once zip tied there it will not budge due to that being the slimmest section.

title: Tetrix to Hitec Standard Servo Thru Mount - V8

description.text:
Mounts a standard Hitec servo with a servo horn and axle hub on a Tetrix channel, with the servo and axle hub aligned to a large Tetrix hole. This provides better support for the servo and protection against side shocks to the axle. It can also be used with the Tetrix Rack and Pinion set for driving the pinion gear with low loads.
Requires seven 6-32 x 0.75" screws.

• Print both pieces.
  • Insert 3 nuts into the nut holder circles on the servo-side piece. If these don't slide in easily, you can screw through the piece and tighten the screw to pull the nuts into their positions. Then loosen and remove the screws and the nuts should stay in place.
  • Attach the servo horn and axle hub to the servo. No horn screw is needed as the horn and hub will be securely sandwiched between the servo and the tetrix channel. Align the axle hub set screw with the top of the servo for later access. Optionally attach the axle now.
  • Attach the servo to the servo-side piece with four 6-32 x 0.75" screws and four nuts.
  • Sandwich the tetrix-side piece between the tetrix channel and the servo.
  • Fasten everything together by screwing three 6-32 x 0.75" screws through the channel, the tetrix-side piece, the servo-side piece, and into the three nuts previously mounted in the servo-side piece.
  • Optionally attach the top of the tetrix-side piece with two more short, standard tetrix screws and nuts.
  • If you didn't do it already, insert the axle and any associated bushings or set collars and tighten the set screw through the hole at the top.

comments.text: Thanks so much for making this!  This made making a rack and pinion controlled by a servo so much easier!

Do you want to charge your phone, but there is no table nearby?  This allows you to put a shelf on the outlet with your charger. Since it is flat (until you fold it), it is easy to pack in your luggage.  The print is quick and uses very little plastic so if you leave it in the hotel room, it's no big deal.  To use it, simply fold it and put your charger through the plug holes.  I printed it with a 0.4 mm nozzle and 0.2 mm layer height.  Many thanks to DesignMakeTeach who gave me the idea for foldable designs.

description.text:
The Laing is a great pump for the water but vibrates and become very hot, especially if leaning into the pc.
The solution is simple: raise the pump it to circulate the air and put some rubber for vibrations.

1- Print it, no support needed. I have used 30% infill.
2- Use a bit of glue to glue some pieces of rubber on the feet.
3- Mounting it on the pump Required components :
  • 2 x M6 bolt
  • 4 x M6 washer
  • 2 x M6 nut

I noticed that the Wade didn't print out well without support, so I hacked my DC Wade variant to use a stepper motor. This design uses the same driven gear and bearing block as the standard Wade and my DC variant. I have added a collar to the drive gear to extend it past the motor bracket.
This updated design has a thicker motor bracket, more room for the drive gear, shorter fixing slots for the stepper, and simplified mounting for the dual 608 bearings on the driven shaft.

The PTFE spacer (default 18mm diameter) is held in with two 25mm No. 4 woodscrews to facilitate replacement. The small hole in the top near the filament hole is for attaching a piece of terminal strip. Use two M8 nuts at one end of the drive shaft, two 608 bearings in the middle, a couple of M8 washers, an M8 nut and then the big gear with an M8 nut in the centre of it.
Only 2 off 16mm x M3 screws and washers are really needed to hold the NEMA17 down.

description.text: My shower handle broke so why not make it better? This was a simple replacement, stronger then original by many times because it is not hollow like the original was.  It also allows the Hot and Cold screw covers to fit in. I printed with support, it was simple to print. Easier to turn because the ridges help the wet hands grab and I made the spikes and valleys deeper for good grip.
A test to see how well the Makerbot Replicator does at spanning a distance

This was a demo for students to show how it's possible for a horizontal shape to span two points without anything underneath. In other words, it's a special type of overhang. It also demonstrates how a 45 degree hole at the bottom of the model works out fine.  The two spans required about 6 or so passes to make.  The first pass works fine with no visible sag.  The subsequent passes also work fine.  The only detail is that the first pass is cold by the time the next layer of filament is laid on top of it, so it was possible to separate it into "strands".  Of course this all only works with a horizontal span.

Niagara Falls - Constructed using 1 arcsecond resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle. This is using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL. I hope to release the new software as soon as I get any kinks out.

You may want to print this to be relatively small. I get warping using PLA and it gets bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. I have had 'some' success with big maps. If you have a way to control warping you may also have better luck with big maps.

title: Mini active carbon filter housing. Fits 40mm exhaust fan.

description.text:
Mini active carbon filter housing. Fits 40mm exhaust fan.
Tools needed....
1.) 3D Printer
2.) Scrubber pad / Scotchbright pad
3.) Hot glue gun
4.) 2 Tbsp Active Carbon , Coffee ground size
5.) 40mm exhaust fan
6.) Scissors

Step 1.) Print the housing assembly
Step 2.) Cut 2 pcs of scrubber pad to fit the head and cap of housing
Step 3.) Glue the edges of one pad to the inside of the head housing
Step 4.) Fill the head housing with 2 Tbsp of active carbon
Step 5.) Glue the edges of one pad to the inside of the cap housing
Step 6.) While the glue on the cap is still hot, press the housing together until cool.
Step 7.) Place 1 or 2 drops of hot glue into the mouting hole on the head side.
Step 8.) Place the fan on the head side
Step 8.) Press the studs into the mounting holes.

title: Laser Cut Laptop Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I had 6mm MDF scrap in my garage and I didn't feel like going to the hardware store to get a 3mm (?1/8") sheet, so I modified 300dpi's Laptop/Tablet Stand to work with 6mm (?1/4") MDF.
I have simplified the design to only include what you need to make one stand; not a separate stand for the laptop and tablet. I have also removed some of the additional notches on the spacers. This should be able to support most laptops up to 15".

Use 6mm material for this project.
I cut this on a 30 Watt Epilogue Mini Helix at 7% speed and 100% power with pretty good results. Your milage may vary, so do some tests with your laser before you cut the whole project. It takes 9:25 to cut at these settings.
For laptops: Use the long struts on the outside. For heavier laptops, also use the short struts on the inside.
For Tablets: Use the short struts on the outside.
Note: I have also added a file with slightly looser connections if you find the connections are too tight for your material.

author: Amadon

description.text:
Had to design something that would fit on the print bed of a Kossel mini. My goal was to keep it simple and use as little filament as possible while still retaining maximum stability.
Works great and can be adjusted for different sized filament spools.
Inspired by: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:479943

2x M8 threaded rod aprox. 125mm long (4.9 inches)
4x M8 nuts
6x M8 washers
6x M8 bearings (Z809)
4x M8 wing nuts
4x Printed spool holders
2x Printed bearing spacers
In the picture I used two M8 locknuts on the side facing the room instead of nuts and washers. This was only done so nothing would snag on the protruding M8 threaded rods, It's completely optional.

I bought the Adafruit Space Invader pendant but I didn't want to just dangle a PCB on my neck, so I made this. You can follow the project on Adafruit's site for all instructions for the electronics. Just print this case off and put it together. Beginner-friendly. Print the battery holder with supports. Print everything else without supports but you may need either a brim or printing disks (put these at the pointy parts) because of the sharp corners (which may pull up off your bed if it's not heated). Top and bottom snap together but you'll need a couple of small screws and nuts for the battery holder. Optionally, change out the JST connectors for something more rational. Finally, I made mine without a switch and just programmed it to loop forever.
.
To get it back apart, just squeeze the bottom part and pry it apart. Program your Gemma before you put it together and you won't ever have to take it apart (provided you've used alternative JSTs) unless you tire of the animations.
.
To ensure proper orientation, mount it so that what would normally be the necklace part if you were just dangling the PCB is pointing towards the small necklace holes, or away from the big battery hole. The big battery hole goes at the bottom. There is enough room inside so that if you don't get the wire lengths quite right, it'll be fine. You may need to stick one piece of wire underneath the opposite side of the backpack so that it sits evenly (you'll understand when you do it).

Fast, easy, fun, lazy: lazor cut a party mask!

Vector designs for simple paper masks you can laser cut.
Etch any blue lines (raster) and cut the black lines (vector). All lines are set to 3 points in the .SVG. Please adjust black cutting lines as needed for vector cuts ( hairline / .001 points, etc.)
Recommended materials: colored papers like heavy 110# or higher cardstock paper, poster board, cereal box chipboard packaging, 150# tagboard paper. Crayons, markers, acrylic paint, poster paint, glitter glue, glow in the dark paint or tempera paint are some art material ideas.
Use a hole punch to position the mask on the face and use elastic cord to hold the mask on. Tape is recommended to reinforce the back of where the hole is punched, try duct or packing tape. Expand the .SVG file and re-size or re-position the eye holes as needed.
Happy Halloween!

title: 4" Bag Clip in PLA  Fully Assembled

description.text:
This is a remix of MasterFX's PLA Compatible Bag Clip. This
version is manifold and I made it longer for larger bags. Also check
out the double seal version http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:498030
.
It's actually a little over 4" long, but will fit on a 100x100 print bed if
you rotate the z axis 23 degrees and the re-center the part; although you either need to skip the skirt, or bring it in very close to the print
(around 0.5mm does work on a 100x100 print bed). It prints well
on my Printrbot SImple.
.
I printed in PLA with .2mm layers and 33% infill, no support.
Note that you'll need a well calibrated machine to get the hinge
to print so that it separates and swivels correctly.
.
Once complete, gently bend the parts back and forth holding it
near the center hinge. You'll feel it click loose and then should
swivel freely.

title: Dive Spear for LionFish Hunting 3D Printable

description.text:
Lionfish are the first exotic species to invade coral reefs. They have multiplied at a rate that is almost unheard of in marine history, going from nonexistent to pervasive in just a few short years. Along the way, they've eaten or starved out local fish, disrupted commercial fishing, and threatened the tourism industry. Some experts believe that lionfish are so widespread that their effect on the ecosystems of the Western Atlantic will be almost impossible to reverse. Still, some people are determined to try, if only to protect those waters which haven't yet been invaded.
Download the world's first 3D-printable spear for lionfish hunting designed by Mold Busters to protect the reefs and the environment.
Read a full article by Shane Graber covering this experiment here -
htttp://www.advancedaquarist.com/blog/controlling-lionfish-with-3d-printed-fish-spears http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_I7ceGg3kCU Check out version2 - fully cutomizable dive spear - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:54756 For more information about our environmental efforts, please visit https://www.bustmold.com/locations/ottawa/ or https://www.bustmold.com/locations/montreal/

Tested on Replicator 2.
Works perfectly at basic settings:
Quality: Medium
Infill: 10%
Number of Shells: 2
Layer height: 0.27 Please send your build comments.

In my small bathroom there is no space for charging my electric toothbrush near an electric socket. So I reprapped a small base to be fixed on a water pipe near an electric socket. No, green is not the best color for this thing.

Print the base (can I recommend the color white?) and use a single m3 bolt with a nut (trapped in the base) to fix it to a water pipe.
The TB-base.stl is the stl used in the pictures. Later I realized that it would have been better to make some holes in the bottom (TB-base2.stl). The holes won't be visible, but they will allow for possible condensation below the charger to escape easier. Printing time will be reduced too.
The shape of this thing depends very much of the type of the toothbrush charger. My toothbrush is a Braun OralB 500 which is very common type, but each type comes with a charger with a slightly different shape. The design is straight forward though. I attached the .blend file in which I used a photo of the bottom of the charger as a background picture. I then traced the outline using bezier curves, converted the curve to a mesh and extruded the shape. The thickness of the wall was created by using a scaled up version of the extruded mesh and subtracting the previous mesh from it. This results in walls which are thicker on the wide sections which may not to be to everybody's taste: feel free to improve on this design!
Check the size of your water pipe. Mine is 12 mm in diameter. The base is snapped on the pipe and the m3 bolt is there to prevent the base from coming loose.

A printable part that lets you attach a strap to the Russian Sputnik Camera.
For some odd reason the designers of the Russian Sputnik Stereo Camera felt that no one would want to use this big bulky thing with a camera strap. Well, I did. So I went ahead and printed out these simple strap lugs. 
They replace the black metal winding knob parts (Shown in the images attached to this page)

-Print out the part (X2)
I printed it at .1mm resolution, with 50% infill. I have included the Gcode for this part as well. -You simply unscrew the screws holding the winding knobs in place, unscrew the black metal knob housing, and replace them with your brand new frehsly printed strap-lugs. -Both Strap-Lugs are identical and will fit either side of the camera. Now, these parts seem plently strong to me, but I can't take any responsibility if you decide to whip your Sputnik around your head and try to fire it off into orbit and the strap lugs break and you end up in the hospital.

Then print out these supports to mount it.

When mounting the lcd pcb in the housing, use longer m3 screws. They need to stick about 10cm outside the back of the lcd housing.
First mount the supports on the base plate. Then mounts the lcd housing on the support. This is a little bit fiddly, because you have to reach in from the back to put the m3 nuts on.

title: Dice - 12 sided (Replaces two regular dice... plus adds outcomes!)

description.text:
Great for board games...
Easier to use than two dice going in different directions plus adds variables that increase the range of possibilities including:
(1) The number "1". Ever landed one square away from something you wanted to land on... with two dice you can't but with this there is a "1" side. Odds are 1 in 12.
(2) Other variations of 12 sided dice do not allow for "doubles". This does... if the arrow under the 2/4/6/8/10/12 (even numbers) points to the person throwing the dice they are credited with a "double". (Refer to explanatory image)
(3) One final variation is that the "2" and "12" are not necessarily a double as with regular dice. With this 12 sided dice whether or not they are doubles in dependant on point (2) above using the arrow system.
Regular adjacent dice faces total "7" when added. In this case adjacent faces add up to 13.
Note: (1) The numbers are well recessed so do not need painting to be clearly visible. If you do decide to colour the numbers I suggest using a very fine felt pen inside the numbers and arrows in preference to paint as paint can run and end up looking messy.
(2) The 6"6" has an arrow under it as it is even and can be a double... the 9 does not have an arrow under it. If you like this take time to check out my other designs!

Print with Raft on... no support required as there is designed in support that helps ensure the lower side face numbers print well (on a Replicator 2). Use 3 or 4 shells and 25% fill or greater (to increase weight).
The support is designed to snap away reasonably easily with a craft knife (when printed on a Replicator 2 and 5th Generation Replicator) but can be affected by the filament used and the positioning (angle) on the build plate.

comments.text: Understand that... 36 possibilities.
comments.author: muzz64

comments.text: his point was that with 2 regular dice, you are much more likely to get a 7 (3&4, 5&2, 6&1) than you are a 2 (1&1).  with this one all numbers are equally probable...which might be beneficial for some games, but it is definitely different from two 6 sided dice
comments.author: muzz64

comments.text: Just FYI, this WON'T replace two 6-sided dice as rolling two 6-sided dice has a vastly different probability curve for the sum of the 2 dice, than rolling a 12-sided dice alone (in which case each side has a 1/12 probability). Most games that use two 6-sided dice take the probability of, say, rolling a 7 into account so this die would break those game mechanics.
comments.author: pmarreck
